Scheme 3 Mechanisms for dehydration and dehydrogenation of 2-propanol over acid and base catalysts. Scheme 4 Synthesis of MIBK from acetone. Scheme 5 Mechanisms proposed for Tishchenko reaction of aldehyde. Scheme 6 Metathesis of ethylene and butane to produce propylene. Scheme 7 Reaction pathway for ethanol to 1-3,butadiene. Scheme 8 Pathway for side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol to styrene. Table 1 Types of solid base catalysts. (1) Single component metal oxides – alkaline earth metal oxides: MgO, CaO, SrO, BaO – rare earth oxides: La2O3, Sm2O3 – other oxides: Al2O3, ZrO2, Y2O3, ZnO, TiO2, MoO3, ThO2 (2) Double components metal oxide – ZnO–Al2O3, MgO–TiO2 (3) Zeolites – alkali ion-exchanged zeolites: Na–X, Cs–X – alkali ion-added zeolites: Cs2O/Cs–X (4) Supported alkali metal compounds – alkali metal compounds on alumina: Na0/Al2O3, Na2O/Al2O3 – alkali metal compound on silica: Na0/SiO2, Na2O/SiO2 – alkali metal ions on alkaline earth oxides: Na2O/MgO (5) Clay minerals – hydrotalcite: Mg6Al2(OH)16CO3 ·4H2O – chrysolite: Mg3(Si2O5)O3(OH)4 – sepiolite: Mg4Si6O15(OH)2 (6) Non-oxide – KF supported on alumina: KF/Al2O3 – lanthanide imide and nitride on zeolite – metal oxynitrides: ALPON, VALPON Table 2 Base-catalyzed reactions studied in our laboratories. 1. Industry sector Annual production (ton) E-factor Waste produced (ton) Oil refining 106–108 ca. 0.1 105–107 Bulk chemicals 104–106 <1–5 104–5×106 Fine chemicals 102–104 5–50 5×102–5×105 Pharmaceuticals 101–103 25–100 2.5×102–105 Solid base catalysts: fundamentals and their applications in organic reactions Hideshi Hattori ⁎ Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University, Kita-ku, N-21, W-10, Sapporo 001-0021, Japan Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University Kita-ku, N-21, W-10 Sapporo 001-0021 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Solid base catalysis studied over the last a half of century is reviewed briefly including mainly those performed in our laboratories. The review begins with advantages of solid base catalysts over homogeneous base catalyst in industrial use followed by definition of Brϕnsted base and Lewis base. The materials known as solid base catalysts are listed, and four reasons for which these materials are recognized as solid base catalyst are explained. For all solid base catalysts, variations in activity as a function of pretreatment temperature show a volcano shape; an incline with the temperature results from an appearance of basic sites by removal of water and carbon dioxide from the surface and a decline results from an elimination of basic sites by rearrangement of surface atoms. The reactions catalyzed by solid base catalysts can be classified into three types: double bond isomerization, addition of anion and proton to various double bonds, and alcohol decomposition. These are represented by 1-butene isomerization, hydrogenation of conjugated 1,3-butadiene and dehydration of 2-butanol. Their mechanisms are explained. In addition, bifunctional base-catalyzed reactions in which basic sites participate in one step of successive steps are exemplified for methyl isobutyl ketome synthesis, metathesis, Tishchenko reaction and side-chain alkylation of toluene. Some industrial processes and future perspectives are briefly described. Keywords Solid base Base-catalyzed reaction Organic reaction Generation of basic site Bifunctional catalysis 1 Introduction Study of solid base catalysts started in 1958 with a series of investigations by Pines and Haag [1]. They reported that alkali metal-supported alumina showed catalytic activity for double bond isomerization of alkenes that proceeded via carbanions as intermediates. In 1970's, a number of metal oxides other than those containing alkali metals were found to show catalytic activities for base-catalyzed reactions. In contrast to solid acid catalysts which were already used in industrial processes, we had to wait more than two decades until solid base catalysts were used practically. Advantages of solid base catalysts over liquid base catalysts in industrial use are as follows: 1. Neutralization of reaction mixture is not required. In liquid base-catalyzed reactions, neutralization of the base is required, while in solid base-catalyzed reactions, neutralization step is not required. Neutralization produces waste which can be minimized by use of solid base catalysts. 2. High temperature reaction is possible. Since solvents are normally used in liquid base-catalyzed reactions, the reaction temperature is limited below boiling temperature under an atmospheric pressure. There is no limitation of the reaction temperature for solid base-catalyzed reactions. 3. Employment of flow reactor system makes the process highly productive. 4. Separation of catalysts from products is easy, and recycled use of spent catalyst is possible. 5. Use of base-tolerant materials is not required for reactor system. 6. Bifunctional (dual functional) catalysis is possible. On the surfaces of solid bases, co-existence of basic sites and acidic sites is possible, while it is impossible in liquid phase. 7. There are some reactions specific to solid base catalysts. Heterolytic spritting of H2 into H+ and H− has not been observed for liquid base, while it is observed for solid base and the initial step for base-catalyzed hydrogenation of conjugated dienes. 2 Brϕnsted base and Lewis base In the definition by Brϕnsted–Lowley, a base B− accepts a proton from a reactant. In the definition by Lewis, a base B donates an electron pair to a reactant. Basic sites (B) abstract a proton from the reactant molecules (AH) to form anions (A−). (1) B+AH→BH+ +A− Here, the basic site B− on the surface acts as a Brϕnsted base. Examples of this type of the formation of anionic intermediates are 1-butene isomerization where an H+ is abstracted from C3 position to form allylic anion, and aldol condensation and Knoevenagel condensation where an H+ is abstracted from ketone with α-H to form anions. Basic sites (B) donate an electron pair to form anionic intermediates. For example, ketones can be activated without proton transfer. (2) B+A→B–A An example of this type of acid–base interaction is (3) H3N:+BF3 →H3N: BF3 Here, the basic site acts as a Lewis base. An example of this type for base-catalyzed reaction is Tishchenko reaction where basic site donates an electron pair to the carbonyl C atom to form anionic intermediate. It should be noted that the same surface site can serve as either Brϕnsted base (proton acceptor) or Lewis base (electron pair donor) depending on the nature of the reactant. The naming of base should be based on its function (H+ abstraction or electron pair donation). 3 Solid base catalysts Types of solid base catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The reasons for which these catalysts are recognized as solid base catalysts are as follows. 1. Characterization of the surfaces indicates the existence of basic sites. Color change of the acid–base indicators, adsorption of acidic molecules and spectroscopies indicate that basic sites exist on the surfaces. 2. Catalytic activities correlated with the amount or strength of basic sites. In addition, the active sites are poisoned by acidic molecules such as CO2, H2O, and HCl. 3. The reactions proceeding over the materials are similar to the “base-catalyzed reactions” which are well-known in homogeneous systems. These reactions include alkylation, isomerization, Michael addition, aldol addition, Tishchenko reaction, etc. 4. Mechanistic studies of the reactions and spectroscopic observations of the surface species indicate that anionic intermediates are involved in the reactions. 4 Generation of basic sites Because of basic properties, the surfaces of basic materials are covered with CO2 and H2O when exposed to atmospheric environment. In some cases, metal oxides are prepared from metal hydroxides and metal carbonates by decomposition. To remove CO2 and H2O from the surfaces or bulk, pretreatment at a high temperature is required to reveal basic sites on the surfaces. The generation of basic sites and catalytic activity vary with the pretreatment temperature. Fig. 1 shows the variations in the evolution of H2O and CO2 from the starting material Ca(OH)2 and in the catalytic activity for 1-butene isomerization as a function of the pretreatment temperature in a vacuum [2]. In the temperature range 500–600K, dehydration of Ca(OH)2 to CaO takes place, but the surface is still covered with H2O and CO2. At 600K, CO2 and H2O begin to remove from the surface to expose the surface of CaO, and the activity also begins to appear. Appearance of basic sites by removal of CO2 and H2O is commonly observed for solid base catalysts such as MgO, SrO, BaO, La2O3 and Sm2O3, The basic sites appeared by removal of CO2 and H2O are not uniform as shown in Fig. 2 where the surface model of MgO is shown after complete removal of H2O and CO2 [3]. There are ion pairs (Mg2+–O2−) with different coordination numbers. The ion pairs with lower coordination numbers are supposed to be stronger and adsorb CO2 and H2O more strongly than the ion pairs with higher coordination numbers. Therefore, as the pretreatment temperature increases, appearance of basic sites is in the order of increasing basic strength. This reflects on the variation in catalytic activity for different reactions. The reaction that needs stronger basic sites shows an activity maximum at a higher pretreatment temperature. The activity variations of MgO as a function of pretreatment temperature show maximum at 800, 950 and 1300K for 1-butene isomerization, CH4-D2 exchange and 1,3-butadiene hydrogenation, respectively. 1-Butene isomerization, CH4-D2 exchange and 1.3-butadiene hydrogenation require relatively weak basic sites, intermediate basic sites and strong basic sites, respectively [4]. The volcano type variation in the activity as a function of pretreatment temperature is commonly observed for solid base catalysts. The left hand side of the volcano type curve corresponds to the appearance of the basic sites (ion-pairs) active for the reaction, while the right hand side to the elimination of the coordinatively unsaturated ion-pair by rearrangement of the surface atoms as shown in Fig. 3 . It is to be noted that the coordinatively unsaturated metal cations migrate over the surface when CO2 is adsorbed and desorbed. This was evidenced by a tracer study using C18O2. The 18O in C18O2 exchanges with lattice 16O as shown in Fig. 4 . Desorbed CO2 contains 16O. The migration of the coordinatively unsaturated metal cations is also expected to occur when H2O is adsorbed and desorbed [5]. 5 Catalysis by solid base catalysts Table 2 lists the solid base-catalyzed reactions studied in our laboratories. All of these reactions except Tishchenko reaction are initiated by abstraction of an H+ from the reactants by basic sites. Tishchenko reaction is initiated by donation of an electron pair from basic site to the reactants. Some of the reactions listed in Table 2 have similarity each other in mechanism, and the reactions in Table 2 can be classified into three groups. In addition to the reactions listed in Table 2, dehydration of alcohols is another type of base-catalyzed reaction which we have not studied. 5.1 Fundamental reactions by solid base catalysts The mechanisms and roles of basic sites are described here for the following four reactions as representative reactions for the classified four groups: 1-butene isomerization, 1,3-butadiene hydrogenation and decomposition of alcohols. 5.1.1 1-Butene isomerization The reaction proceeds as shown in Scheme 1 . The reaction is initiated by abstraction of an H+ from C3 by basic sites to form cis-allylic carbanions and trans-allylic carbanions. Since, the cis form is more stable than the trans form, the concentration of allylic carbanions is higher in the cis form than in the trans form. The geometrical structure is retained during the addition of an H+ to allylic carbanion; addition of an H+ to the cis form and the trans form results in the formation of cis-2-butene and trans-2-butene, respectively. Accordingly, cis-2-butene is predominantly formed over trans-2-butene in the initial stage of 1-butene isomerization. Direct interconversion between the cis form and the trans form has a high energy barrier to cross over since theC2-C3 bond has a double bond character. Accordingly, in the initial stage of cis-2-butene isomerization, 1-butene is predominantly formed over trans-2-butene even the equilibrium concentration of 1-butene is low. In the butene isomerization, intramolecular H transfer is involved. The H atom that is abstracted from a molecule returns to the same molecule to form the isomerized product. This is in contrast to acid-catalyzed butene isomerization in which intermolecular H transfer is involved. The occurrence of intramolecular H transfer can be evidenced by coisomerization of a mixture of C4H8 (d 0): C4D8 (d 8) with a 1:1 ratio. The isomerized butane isomers consist essentially of d 0 and d 8 isomers, no d 1 and d 7 being formed [6]. The activity of solid base catalysts for double bond isomerization is generally high as compared to solid acid catalysts. Due to the high activity of solid base catalysts for double bond isomerization together with no cracking activity, solid base catalysts are active and selective catalysts for double bond isomerization of the unsaturated hydrocarbons as shown in Fig. 5 [7–9]. These unsaturated hydrocarbons have three, four or five membered rings which are unstable and easy to open when acid catalysts are used. Because solid base catalysts do not cleaveC-C bonds, only double bond isomerization takes place. The mechanisms of the double bond isomerization are initiated by abstraction of an H+ followed by intramolecular H transfer as those observed for butene isomerization. The reactions occur at a low temperature to avoid the formation of by-products. Isomerization of 5-vinylbicyclo[2.2.1]hept-2-ene to 5-ethylidenebicyclo[2.2.1]hept-2-ene (reaction 6), which is an important third comonomer of etene–propene synthetic rubber, has been industrialized by use of a solid base catalyst, Na/NaOH/Al2O3 [10]. One more advantage of solid base catalysts over solid acid catalysts is the activity for the double bond isomerization of unsaturated compounds containing heteroatoms. While solid acid catalysts are poisoned by the reactants containing heteroatoms such as N and O, solid base catalysts are not poisoned. Examples of the unsaturated compounds containing heteroatoms are allyl amines [11] and allyl ethers [12,13]. 5.1.2 Hydrogenation Some solid base catalysts such as alkaline earth oxides, rare earth oxides, and ZrO2 catalyze hydrogenation of alkenes in particular conjugated alkadienes. The mechanism of hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene over MgO is shown in Scheme 2 in which H atoms are replaced by D atoms [14,15]. Deuterium molecules are heterolytically dissociated into D− and D+ on Mg2+–O2− pair. 1,3-Butadiene consists of 93% s-trans and s-trans conformers in gas phase at 273K. The D− attacks 1,3-butadiene to form mostly the trans form of allylic anion which undergoes either interconversion to form more stable cis-allylic anion or addition of D+ to form trans-2-butene. Since the electron density of allylic anion is the highest on the terminal C atom, positively charged D+ selectively adds to the terminal C to complete 1,4-addition of D atoms to yield 2-butene isomers. If the interconversion of the allylic anion is faster than the addition of D+, cis-2-butene-d 2 is obtained as the main product which is observed for MgO. On the other hand, if the addition is faster than the interconversion, trans-2-butene-d 2 is obtained as the main product which is observed for ZrO2, ThO2 and La2O3. In base-catalyzed hydrogenation, conjugated alkadienes are much more reactive than alkenes. For example, 1,3-butadiene hydrogenation proceeds at 273K over MgO, while 1-butene hydrogenation proceed above 473K. This is caused by the difference in stability of the intermediate anions. The intermediate anions for the hydrogenation of conjugated alkadienes are allylic carbanions which are stable, while the intermediate anions for hydrogenation of alkenes are alkyl carbanions which are not so stable as allylic carbanions. In the hydrogenation of alkadienes over solid base catalyst, alkenes are selectively formed, alkanes are scarcely formed. A key step in base-catalyzed hydrogenation is a heterolytic dissociation of H2 into an H+ and H-, which can be said an abstraction of an H+ from H2 molecule. A compound possessing H (X–H) dissociates heterolytically to H+ and X−, and X− adds to a molecule to form carbanion and then the H+ add to the carbanion to complete a base-catalyzed addition. This reaction scheme is widely applicable for base-catalyzed addition and condensation reactions. Examples are amination, Michael addition reactions (nucleophilic conjugate addition), aldol addition, nitroaldol reaction, cyanoethylation, Knoevenagel condensation, etc. Therefore, base-catalyzed hydrogenation of conjugated dialkadiene is one of the fundamental base-catalyzed reactions. 5.1.3 Decomposition of alcohols Alcohols undergo dehydration and dehydrogenation over acid and base catalysts. Three mechanisms are known as dehydration of alcohols, E1, E2, and E1cB. E1 mechanism is acid-catalyzed dehydration, E2 acid–base concerted mechanism, and E1cB base-catalyzed dehydration, which are shown in Scheme 3 taking an example of 2-propanol decomposition. Over solid base catalysts, dehydration and dehydrogenation occur depending on the type of catalyst and reactant. For both reactions, the initial step is abstraction of an H+ from alcohols by basic sites to form anions. Abstraction of carbonyl H yields aldehydes or ketones, while abstraction of α-H yields olefins. For most of solid base catalysts, alcohols undergo dehydrogenation. For some solid base catalysts such as ZrO2, ThO2, and rare earth oxides, dehydration proceeds. Base-catalyzed dehydration of 2-butanol yields 1-butene by E1cB mechanism via primary carbanion, while acid-catalyzed dehydration of 2-butanol yields a mixture of butane isomers by E1 mechanism via secondary carbenium ion. This is caused by the different intermediates between E1cB and E1. Primary carbanion is more stable than secondary carbanion, while secondary carbocation is more stable than primary carbocation. Preferential formation of α-olefins from 2-alcohols by base-catalyzed dehydration is utilized for the industrial process of the production of vinylcyclohexane. Cyclohexylethanol is dehydrated to form selectively to α-olefin, vinylcyclohexane, over ZrO2 [16]. 5.2 Bifunctional catalysis There are many reactions that need different catalytic functions to complete. Basic sites can co-exist with other sites having different catalytic functions. Metal oxide catalysts have both basic site (surface O atom) and acidic site (surface metal ion) without addition of other components. Combinations of solid base catalysts with metallic catalyst, and with metathesis catalyst as well as combination of two kinds of solid base catalysts are described below. 5.2.1 Methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK) synthesis from acetone MIBK is commercially produced in three steps from acetone; aldol addition of acetone to diacetone alcohol (DAA), acid-catalyzed dehydration of DDA to mesityl oxide (MO) and selective hydrogenation of MO to MIBK as shown in Scheme 4 . For the synthesis of MIBK from acetone, solid base-supported metal were examined [17]. Pd supported on KOH–Al2O3 and MgO–SiO2, Ni/MgO, Na/Pd/MgO, and Ni or Pd supported on Mg/Al hydrotalcite were reported as efficient catalysts for this reaction. The first step (aldol addition) is catalyzed by solid base. The second step (dehydration) proceeds over solid acid catalyst. The third step (hydrogenation) is catalyzed by metallic catalysts. Too much hydrogenation activity results in further hydrogenation to alcohol. Balance of acidic, basic properties and hydrogenation ability is important to have a high yield. 2-Ethyl-1-hexanal can be produced from n-butanal also by successive of aldol addition, dehydration and hydrogenation. It was reported that Pd supported on solid base catalyst Na/SiO2 acted as an efficient catalyst [17]. 5.2.2 Tishchenko reaction The aldehydes with no α-H undergo Tishchenko reaction to form esters over solid base catalysts, while those with α-H undergo aldol addition. Alkaline earth oxides such as MgO, CaO, SrO and BaO act as efficient catalysts for Tishchenko reaction [18]. The reaction over metal oxide catalyst is initiated by basic sites and driven by acidic sites (metal cation). A basic site donates an electron pair to the carbonyl C of aldehyde, which is followed by an interaction of the negatively charged carbonyl O with the positively charged carbonyl C of another aldehyde adsorbed on the metal cation. This is a type of acid–base bifunctional catalysis. By tracer study in which lattice O of the catalyst surface was substituted with 18O, incorporation of the lattice O into the product was observed. The reaction mechanisms for Tishchenko reaction of aldehyde was proposed as shown in Scheme 5 [19]. It is to be noted that the coordinatively unsaturated metal cations migrate over the surface during the reaction just like what is observed on adsorption–desorption of CO2 (Fig. 4) [5]. 5.2.3 Production of propylene by metathesis of ethylene and butane Reaction of ethylene with 2-butene yields propene by the productive metathesis, but the reaction of ethylene with 1-butene does not yield propene because of non-productive metathesis. As ethylene and a mixture of butane isomers are allowed to react over metathesis catalyst, only 1-butene is consumed and 2-butene isomers remain unreacted (Scheme 6 ). To enhance the yield of propylene, 2-butene isomers should be isomerized to 1-butene. Therefore, in addition to the active sites for metathesis, those for isomerization need to co-exist in the catalyst. Banks and Kukes [20] used a catalyst composed of WO3/SiO2 and MgO for the reaction of ethylene and butane isomers. The particles of WO3/SiO2 and those of MgO were physically mixed. The yield of propene was significantly higher over the mixed catalyst than over WO3/SiO2 alone. This is the base of Lummus olefin conversion technology (OCT). Selection of the isomerization catalyst is a key to enhance the productivity of the process. Solid base catalysts were examined for isomerization of butene isomers under the metathesis conditions. Miyazoe et al. [21] disclosed the efficient catalysts in a patent. A high propene yield was obtained over the catalysts composed of WO3/SiO2 metathesis catalyst and isomerization catalysts in the presence of hydrogen at 448K. Isomerization catalysts include rare earth oxides (Y2O3 or La2O3), alkaline earth oxide (MgO) and Al2O3. Catalyst particles of two types of catalysts, metathesis catalyst and isomerization catalyst, were physically mixed. Two types of catalyst work independently. The propene yield persisted a high value as far as isomerization activity was kept high. A positive effect of hydrogen is plausibly due to removal of poisons containing in the feed such as alkadienes and acetylenic compounds. 5.2.4 Synthesis of 1,3-butadiene from ethanol Ethanol converts to 1,3-butadiene over SiO2–MgO at 653K [22]. This is another example of the bifunctional catalysis in which both acidic site and basic site participate in different steps. A plausible reaction pathway is shown in Scheme 7 . Ethanol undergoes dehydrogenation over basic site to formaldehyde which further undergoes aldol addition over base followed by dehydration over acidic site to crotonaldehyde. Crotonaldehyde undergoes transfer hydrogenation with ethanol over acid–base site to form crotyl alcohol which undergoes dehydration over acidic site to finally form 1.3-butadiene. Co-existence of acidic sites and basic sites is required for this reaction. 5.2.5 Synthesis of styrene by side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol Reaction of toluene with methanol over basic zeolites yields styrene and ethylbenzene [23,24]. The reaction proceeds as shown in Scheme 8 . Methanol undergoes dehydrogenation to form formaldehyde (step 1) which reacts with toluene by aldol-type reaction to form styrene (step 3). Styrene further reacts with methanol to convert into ethylbenzene and formaldehyde by transfer hydrogenation (step 2). In addition to these reactions, methanol decomposes to CO and hydrogen (step 4). For production of styrene, steps 1 and 3 are compulsory, but occurrence of steps 2 and 4 lowers the yield of styrene. Basic sites are involved in all the steps, but efficient basic sites are different for each step. Strong basic sites are required for the step 1 in which abstraction of an H+ from toluene is involved. However, too strong basic sites promote the steps 2 and 4 to lower the yield of styrene. Weak basic sites promote step 1, but cannot abstract an H+ from toluene. Accordingly a balanced combination of strong and weak basic sites is desirable for a high yield of styrene. We have examined the effects of several additives to Cs ion-exchanged zeolite X (Cs–X) and Cs-added zeolite X which contains Cs in excess of the ion-exchange capacity (Cs2O/Cs–X), and found ZrB2O5 was an efficient additive to Cs–X. The role of ZrB2O5 was estimated to enhance selective dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde [25–27]. 6 Industrial processes Industrial processes using solid base catalysts up to 1999 were summarized by Tanabe and Hoelderich which are listed in Table 3 [28]. To Table 3, a new process of transesterification of triglyceride with methanol using ZnO–Al2O3 to produce biodiesel in 2005 is to be added [29]. Except two processes started in 1970 and 1973, all the processes started operation after 1988. It took about 20 years that solid base catalysts were utilized in industrial processes since the fundamental studies of solid base catalyst started in 1970s. This is similar to the case of solid acid catalysts; it took about 20 years that many solid acid-catalyzed processes explosively appeared in 1970s since the fundamental studies of solid acid catalysts started in about 1950. In both cases, the fundamental studies are important for realization of industrial catalytic processes. The time lag between fundamental study and practical utilization was about 20 years for both acid and base catalysis. The process of isobutyraldehyde to diisopropyl ketone by use of ZrO2 started operation in 1973 [30]. It was 10 years before ZrO2 catalyst was found to possess basic sites on the surface in 1983 [31]. ZrO2 was used without knowing its acid–base properties. The process of isobutyraldehyde to diisopropyl ketone involves Tishchenko reaction, hydration, dehydrogenation, decarbonation and dehydration. It was later revealed that all reactions proceed by basic and acidic sites on ZrO2. 7 Future perspective Table 4 lists the E-factors in four chemical industry sectors; oil refining, bulk chemicals, fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals. E-factor is defined as “weight of waste/weight of product” [32]. Among the sectors, solid base catalysts are being used in the bulk and fine chemicals sectors. Although the annual productions of these sectors are not as large as that of oil refining, the amounts of waste produced are comparable to that produced in oil refining. The number of processes in bulk and fine chemicals sectors that use solid base catalysts is limited at present. There should be many processes in which homogeneous base catalysts are being used but will be able to be replaced by solid base catalysts. There seems to be a sufficient room in the current industrial processes for solid base catalysts to replace the homogeneous catalysts. References [1] H. Pines W.O. Haag J. Org. coredata.dc:description: Solid base catalysis studied over the last a half of century is reviewed briefly including mainly those performed in our laboratories. The review begins with advantages of solid base catalysts over homogeneous base catalyst in industrial use followed by definition of Brϕnsted base and Lewis base. The materials known as solid base catalysts are listed, and four reasons for which these materials are recognized as solid base catalyst are explained. For all solid base catalysts, variations in activity as a function of pretreatment temperature show a volcano shape; an incline with the temperature results from an appearance of basic sites by removal of water and carbon dioxide from the surface and a decline results from an elimination of basic sites by rearrangement of surface atoms. The reactions catalyzed by solid base catalysts can be classified into three types: double bond isomerization, addition of anion and proton to various double bonds, and alcohol decomposition. These are represented by 1-butene isomerization, hydrogenation of conjugated 1,3-butadiene and dehydration of 2-butanol. Their mechanisms are explained. In addition, bifunctional base-catalyzed reactions in which basic sites participate in one step of successive steps are exemplified for methyl isobutyl ketome synthesis, metathesis, Tishchenko reaction and side-chain alkylation of toluene. Some industrial processes and future perspectives are briefly described.
coredata.dc:title: Solid base catalysts: fundamentals and their applications in organic reactions
